item.title: Explaining my Obsidian to Hugo Workflow
item.description: Where We Left Off I was just able to get my website viewable for the first time in Hugo’s draft view. I worked through the formatting errors that my Hugo theme wasn’t compatible with, and everything is looking good. Implementing Git was also incredibly simple. If you don’t know anything about Git, you can start by reading my analysis of a beginner Git textbook. Since Hugo requires you using a separate directory for content, just initialize a new repo in your directory, connect it to a GitHub repo, and you’re off to the races.

item.title: Getting Started with Hugo
item.description: Quick Start It’s remarkably easy to start using Hugo. So much so it makes me want to start working on my portfolio immediately. To start, we need to use PowerShell instead of Windows PowerShell. Apparently, they are different. You also need to have Git installed. Once both are done, you can run the following commands: hugo new site quicksite This creates a new directory that will become our new website.
